Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Making code-based analyses widely accessible for modeling species niches and distributions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Environmental biologists model both where organisms live, their distribution in space (biogeography) and how they interact with the local environment, filling a particular niche. To do this modeling requires data from a number of sources and the use of multiple analytical packages: putting these together in useful workflows requires specialized technical abilities. This proposal will create a software application, called 'Wallace', that brings together the data and analytical components through a graphical interface to make selection of components easier, saves the workflow so others can rerun it, and provides guidance for the best settings for the analyses. It will also provide interactive maps, tables and graphs to explore the results. The application has been designed to be easily extended, and the software will be managed as an open-source, freely available resource through Github. Among other advances, results from using the software will lead to better estimates in conservation biology, invasive species, and the impact of climate change.

A substantial divide exists in environmental biology between researchers with and without strong coding skills: the proposed activities aims to close that gap, using an innovative approach to software development that could transform the field. In the initial phase, The project will release the software application 'Wallace', to enable best computational modeling practices for the burgeoning field of niche/distributional modeling. This software is a modular web application (that also can be run locally) offering customizable workflows through a Graphical User Interface (GUI). It will be built using the recently developed R package shiny, which will allow easy extensibility to the many cutting-edge methods now being produced in the field, via the addition of R packages. Specifically, Wallace will: 1) harness data either from online databases or input by the user; 2) assemble a variety of tools for building and evaluating models; 3) give guidance text for critical conceptual and methodological issues; 4) feature interactive maps, tables, and graphs to view and explore data and model predictions; 5) offer results for download in multiple forms after each stage of the analysis; and 6) provide documented and executable code for rerunning the entire analysis at the end of a user session. Its modular nature will facilitate later addition of new elements by other researchers as the software matures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Even though scientific progress depends on analyses run by computer code, many biologists prefer to use software programs that can be used with a mouse and keyboard (Graphical User Interface; GUI). In this project, the researchers aimed to develop an innovative approach to close that gap, making cutting-edge advances (from computer code) easily accessible through a GUI. Specifically, the activities here focused on producing software called Wallace (named after Alfred Russel Wallace, who pioneered the research area linking biology and geography: biogeography). This new software is free, and its underlying code is available via the Internet. Wallace allows users to estimate the geographic range of a species. It does so using two kinds of data: the places where the species has been found, and climate and other factors likely to affect its range. The Wallace software helps users obtain relevant data from the Internet, understand important uses and limitations of the techniques, make and evaluate predictions of a species' range, visualize the results on graphs and maps, and document the analyses (so they can be reproduced later). Additionally, Wallace was built as a series of modules, making it easier to expand later by contributions from other researchers who could add new modules for techniques that they have developed. The team also responded to user feedback (fixing bugs and noting suggestions for future improvements).

 

The project contributed to student training and outreach, as well as served as an example for future software development. One Ph.D. student did dissertation research directly associated with the project, and several other students and collaborators also participated. The project directly led to or contributed to four scientific publications. The researchers gave four presentations and ran a workshop. The software makes information on species ranges more accessible to users, from scientists and natural resource managers/conservation biologists to students and educators. Additionally, Wallace serves as an example for the development of software in other areas of science.
